questions.text: Which type of aphasia is characterized by fluent speech, but impaired comprehension and repetition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Broca's aphasia: Broca's aphasia is non-fluent with effortful speech, but relatively preserved comprehension.
  • • Option A. Broca's aphasia:
  • • Option C. Global aphasia: Global aphasia is a severe impairment of both production and comprehension of language.
  • • Option C. Global aphasia:
  • • Option D. Conduction aphasia: Conduction aphasia is characterized by fluent speech, relatively good comprehension, but impaired repetition.
  • • Option D. Conduction aphasia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Differentiate Wernicke's aphasia from other types by its characteristic fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman has progressively worsening difficulty finding words during conversations. Her speech is fluent, she can follow commands and repeat phrases, but struggles to name common objects. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Broca's aphasia: Broca's aphasia is characterized by non-fluent, effortful speech.
  • • Option A. Broca's aphasia:
  • • Option B. Wernicke's aphasia: Presents with fluent but nonsensical speech and poor comprehension.
  • • Option B. Wernicke's aphasia:
  • • Option D. Global aphasia: Global aphasia is a severe impairment in all aspects of language.
  • • Option D. Global aphasia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize anomic aphasia as a specific type of aphasia primarily affecting word-finding ability.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension and TIAs is found unresponsive. On exam, he's awake but unable to follow commands or produce meaningful speech, only uttering repetitive sounds. He has right-sided hemiparesis and facial droop. CT shows a large left MCA infarct. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Broca's aphasia : Broca's aphasia is non-fluent but comprehension is relatively preserved.
  • • Option A. Broca's aphasia
  • • Option B. Wernicke's aphasia : Wernicke's aphasia is fluent but nonsensical, with poor comprehension.
  • • Option B. Wernicke's aphasia
  • • Option C. Anomic aphasia : Anomic aphasia is primarily a word-finding difficulty with otherwise preserved language.
  • • Option C. Anomic aphasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Understand that global aphasia is the most severe form of aphasia, typically resulting from large lesions in the dominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with hypertension has sudden difficulty reading. Words appear jumbled. He can write and understand spoken language but cannot read what he just wrote. He has right homonymous hemianopia. What is the most likely vascular territory affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Left ACA: ACA strokes affect the medial aspects of the frontal and parietal lobes, causing contralateral leg weakness and sensory loss.
  • • Option A. Left ACA:
  • • Option B. Left MCA: MCA strokes affect the lateral aspects of the brain, causing contralateral face and arm weakness, sensory loss, and aphasia if in the dominant hemisphere.
  • • Option B. Left MCA:
  • • Option C. Right PCA: PCA strokes affect the occipital lobe, causing visual field deficits.
  • • Option C. Right PCA:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize the classic presentation of alexia without agraphia, a syndrome caused by damage to specific regions of the left temporal lobe, often due to stroke.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man experiences a loss of vision in the upper right quadrant of both eyes. Where is the lesion most likely located?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Right parietal lobe: Right parietal lobe lesions cause left inferior quadrantanopia.
  • • Option A. Right parietal lobe:
  • • Option B. Left parietal lobe: Left parietal lobe lesions cause right inferior quadrantanopia.
  • • Option B. Left parietal lobe:
  • • Option C. Right occipital lobe: Right occipital lobe lesions cause left homonymous hemianopia.
  • • Option C. Right occipital lobe:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Understand the anatomy of the visual pathway and how lesions in different locations can cause specific visual field defects.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man has difficulty writing, calculating, distinguishing left from right, and recognizing objects by touch. He has intact speech and follows commands. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Wernicke's aphasia: Affects language comprehension and expression, not these specific skills.
  • • Option A. Wernicke's aphasia:
  • • Option C. Hemispatial neglect: Involves ignoring one side of space, not the deficits seen here.
  • • Option C. Hemispatial neglect:
  • • Option D. Ideomotor apraxia: Ideomotor apraxia is the inability to perform learned motor tasks despite intact motor function.
  • • Option D. Ideomotor apraxia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize Gerstmann syndrome, a rare but classic neurological syndrome with specific deficits related to parietal lobe function.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension presents with sudden right-sided weakness, difficulty walking, confusion, and difficulty following instructions. On exam, he has right lower extremity weakness, urinary incontinence, apraxia, and intact speech. Which artery is most likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Right MCA: Right MCA stroke would cause left-sided weakness, sensory loss, and possible aphasia.
  • • Option A. Right MCA:
  • • Option C. Right PCA: Right PCA stroke would mainly cause visual field deficits.
  • • Option C. Right PCA:
  • • Option D. Left basilar artery: Left basilar artery stroke would result in more widespread brainstem symptoms.
  • • Option D. Left basilar artery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize the distinct clinical features of ACA stroke, particularly the lower extremity weakness, frontal lobe dysfunction, and urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation suddenly becomes impulsive, disinhibited, and has difficulty concentrating. What is the most likely affected brain area?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Parietal lobe: Sensory processing and spatial awareness
  • • Option B. Parietal lobe:
  • • Option C. Temporal lobe: Memory and language
  • • Option C. Temporal lobe:
  • • Option D. Orbitofrontal cortex: Involved in emotional regulation, but not the primary site for these symptoms
  • • Option D. Orbitofrontal cortex:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Understand the role of the prefrontal cortex in executive function, judgment, and social behavior, and recognize the clinical presentation of its dysfunction.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with hypertension has sudden difficulty reading, with words appearing jumbled. He can write and understand spoken language but cannot read what he just wrote. He also has right homonymous hemianopia. Which artery is most likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. ACA: Supplies the medial frontal and parietal lobes, causing contralateral leg weakness and sensory loss.
  • • Option A. ACA:
  • • Option B. MCA: Supplies the lateral frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes, causing contralateral face and arm weakness, sensory loss, and aphasia if in the dominant hemisphere.
  • • Option B. MCA:
  • • Option D. ICA: Main artery supplying the anterior circulation of the brain, occlusion would cause more extensive deficits.
  • • Option D. ICA:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize the specific visual and reading deficits associated with PCA strokes.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation has a sudden onset of difficulty seeing the right half of her visual field in both eyes and an inability to recognize familiar faces. A CT angiogram shows occlusion of the left PCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Left MCA stroke: Would present with right-sided weakness, sensory loss, and possible aphasia.
  • • Option A. Left MCA stroke:
  • • Option B. Left ACA stroke: Typically affects the leg more than the visual field or face recognition.
  • • Option B. Left ACA stroke:
  • • Option D. A right occipital lobe tumor: Could cause a left homonymous hemianopia, but it's less likely to be sudden and wouldn't explain the prosopagnosia.
  • • Option D. A right occipital lobe tumor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Understand that the PCA supplies the occipital lobe (vision) and the inferior temporal lobe (facial recognition), so strokes in this territory can present with these specific deficits.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypercholesterolemia presents with sudden-onset left-sided weakness, numbness, and difficulty speaking and understanding. He has left facial droop, hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and global aphasia. A CT angiogram shows occlusion of the right ICA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Right MCA stroke: Would not explain the full extent of deficits seen here.
  • • Option A. Right MCA stroke:
  • • Option B. Right ACA stroke: Typically affects the leg more than the face and arm.
  • • Option B. Right ACA stroke:
  • • Option D. Right PCA stroke: Would primarily cause visual field deficits.
  • • Option D. Right PCA stroke:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize that ICA strokes can cause extensive deficits due to involvement of both the MCA and ACA territories.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypercholesterolemia has sudden-onset dizziness, nausea, vomiting, right-sided facial numbness, left-sided body numbness, ataxia, hoarse voice, and diminished gag reflex on the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Medial medullary syndrome: Involves contralateral hemiparesis, contralateral proprioceptive loss, and ipsilateral tongue deviation.
  • • Option A. Medial medullary syndrome:
  • • Option C. Basilar artery stroke: Can cause a variety of symptoms, but the specific constellation here is more consistent with lateral medullary syndrome.
  • • Option C. Basilar artery stroke:
  • • Option D. Pontine stroke: Typically presents with bilateral motor deficits, facial weakness, and other cranial nerve palsies.
  • • Option D. Pontine stroke:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize the hallmark features of lateral medullary syndrome, a brainstem stroke with specific crossed sensory and cranial nerve findings.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with hypertension and diabetes has sudden onset of left-sided weakness, drooping left eyelid, double vision when looking to the right, left-sided ptosis, upward and outward deviation of the left eye, and right-sided hemiparesis. What brain structure is most likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Pons: Lesions here can cause various cranial nerve palsies and hemiparesis, but the specific combination points to the midbrain.
  • • Option B. Pons:
  • • Option C. Medial medulla: Medial medullary syndrome involves contralateral hemiparesis, contralateral proprioceptive loss, and ipsilateral tongue deviation.
  • • Option C. Medial medulla:
  • • Option D. Lateral medulla: Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg) involves ipsilateral facial numbness, contralateral body numbness, ataxia, and other cranial nerve deficits.
  • • Option D. Lateral medulla:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize the signs of Weber's syndrome, a midbrain stroke characterized by ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with hypertension and atrial fibrillation is found unresponsive. On exam, she's awake but unable to speak or move any limbs, though she can blink and move her eyes vertically. She has quadriplegia and anarthria but is conscious. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Guillain-Barré syndrome: Guillain-Barré syndrome is a progressive ascending paralysis, not sudden quadriplegia.
  • • Option A. Guillain-Barré syndrome:
  • • Option C. Myasthenia gravis: Causes fluctuating muscle weakness, not sudden and complete paralysis.
  • • Option C. Myasthenia gravis:
  • • Option D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS): ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease with a slower onset.
  • • Option D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize the characteristic features of locked-in syndrome, a devastating condition where patients are fully conscious but unable to move or communicate verbally, except for vertical eye movements and blinking.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypercholesterolemia has sudden double vision, drooping right eyelid, enlarged pupil, and limited eye movement on the right. He also has tremors and ataxia in his left arm and leg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Weber's syndrome: Involves ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.
  • • Option A. Weber's syndrome:
  • • Option C. Claude's syndrome: Involves ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral ataxia, but not the prominent tremor seen here.
  • • Option C. Claude's syndrome:
  • • Option D. Millard-Gubler syndrome: Involves ipsilateral facial palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.
  • • Option D. Millard-Gubler syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize the unique features of Benedikt's syndrome, a midbrain lesion with a combination of oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral movement disorder.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with uncontrolled hypertension presents unconscious with sudden severe headache, vomiting, pinpoint pupils, and a GCS of 6. CT shows a hemorrhage. What is the most likely site of the bleed?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Putamen: Putaminal hemorrhages usually present with contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and homonymous hemianopia.
  • • Option A. Putamen:
  • • Option C. Cerebellum: Cerebellar hemorrhages often present with ataxia and may not cause pinpoint pupils or rapid coma.
  • • Option C. Cerebellum:
  • • Option D.Thalamus: Thalamic hemorrhages usually present with sensory loss, hemiparesis, and upgaze palsy.
  • • Option D.Thalamus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the characteristic features of pontine hemorrhage, a life-threatening condition often associated with hypertension, requiring immediate medical attention.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with uncontrolled hypertension presents unconscious with severe headache, nausea, and left-sided hemiplegia. His right pupil is larger than the left and unreactive to light. CT scan shows a large right-sided intracerebral hemorrhage with midline shift. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ischemic strokes: Ischemic strokes don't usually cause large hemorrhages with midline shift.
  • • Option A. Ischemic strokes:
  • • Option B. Subaracnoid haemorrhage: Subarachnoid hemorrhage would show blood in the subarachnoid space on CT.
  • • Option B. Subaracnoid haemorrhage:
  • • Option D. Brain tumor: While brain tumors can cause mass effect, the acute presentation and history of hypertension favor ICH.
  • • Option D. Brain tumor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the typical presentation and imaging findings of hypertensive ICH, a common type of stroke associated with high blood pressure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with poorly controlled hypertension presents with sudden severe headache, nausea, vomiting, difficulty walking, dysmetria, nystagmus, and a wide-based gait. CT shows a hyperdense lesion in the cerebellum with edema. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Acute ischemic stroke in the PICA territory

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Ischemic stroke in the PICA territory: Would not show a hyperdense lesion on CT in the acute phase.
  • • Option B. Ischemic stroke in the PICA territory:
  • • Option C. Ruptured cerebellar arteriovenous malformation: AVM rupture is less likely given the history of hypertension.
  • • Option C. Ruptured cerebellar arteriovenous malformation:
  • • Option D. Cerebellar abscess: Is less likely due to the acute presentation and absence of infectious signs.
  • • Option D. Cerebellar abscess:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that cerebellar hemorrhages can present with distinct cerebellar signs and are often associated with hypertension.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden left-sided weakness, slurred speech, and multiple microbleeds on MRI. What is the gold standard investigation to confirm the suspected diagnosis of cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA)?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cerebral angiography: Angiography may not show the small vessel changes associated with CAA.
  • • Option A. Cerebral angiography:
  • • Option B. Lumbar puncture: Lumbar puncture may show amyloid-beta, but it's not specific for CAA.
  • • Option B. Lumbar puncture:
  • • Option D. PET scan: PET scan can detect amyloid but may not differentiate CAA from other types of amyloid deposition.
  • • Option D. PET scan:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that while MRI findings and clinical presentation can suggest CAA, brain biopsy remains the gold standard for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient with a history of warfarin use for atrial fibrillation presents with sudden left-sided weakness, slurred speech, and an INR of 4.5. A CT scan reveals a large hyperdense lesion in the right parietal lobe with surrounding edema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Acute ischemic stroke: Ischemic strokes typically do not show hyperdensity on CT in the acute phase.
  • • Option B. Acute ischemic stroke:
  • • Option C. Brain tumor: Brain tumors usually have a more gradual onset and may not cause such acute deficits.
  • • Option C. Brain tumor:
  • • Option D. Subdural hematoma: Subdural hematomas often present as crescent-shaped hyperdensities on CT.
  • • Option D. Subdural hematoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the importance of considering coagulopathy as a cause of intracerebral hemorrhage in patients on anticoagulation therapy.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with chronic headaches presents with a sudden, severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. He has neck stiffness and a positive Brudzinski's sign. CT shows a hyperdense lesion in the right temporal lobe with surrounding edema and blood in the subarachnoid space. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Ruptured cerebral aneurysm with secondary intracerebral hemorrhage

questions.correct_answer: B. Ruptured cerebral aneurysm with secondary intracerebral hemorrhage
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage: Hypertensive ICH wouldn't typically have subarachnoid blood.
  • • Option A. Hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage:
  • • Option C. Brain tumor with hemorrhagic transformation: Brain tumors can bleed, but the acute onset and meningeal signs point to an aneurysm.
  • • Option C. Brain tumor with hemorrhagic transformation:
  • • Option D. Ischemic stroke with hemorrhagic conversion: Ischemic stroke with hemorrhage is less likely to cause such sudden, severe headache and meningeal irritation.
  • • Option D. Ischemic stroke with hemorrhagic conversion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the typical presentation and CT findings of ruptured cerebral aneurysm, a life-threatening condition requiring urgent intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the ICH score used to predict mortality in patients with intracerebral hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Options A, B and C: Are all components of the ICH score.
  • • Options
  • • A, B
  • • C:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the components of the ICH score and its role in predicting outcomes in patients with intracerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has a large right basal ganglia hemorrhage with significant mass effect. Which factor most strongly indicates the need for surgical intervention?

options.label: C
options.text: Hematoma volume > 30 cm3 with clinical deterioration

options.label: D
options.text: Blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg on admission

questions.correct_answer: C. Hematoma volume > 30 cm3 with clinical deterioration
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Age over 70 years: Age is a factor, but not the sole determinant for surgery.
  • • Option A. Age over 70 years:
  • • Option B. Presence of intraventricular haemorrhage: IVH can be managed with external ventricular drainage if needed.
  • • Option B. Presence of intraventricular haemorrhage:
  • • Option D. Blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg on admission: High blood pressure needs to be controlled medically, but it's not an absolute surgical indication.
  • • Option D. Blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg on admission:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the key factors guiding surgical decision-making in intracerebral hemorrhage, with large hematoma and clinical deterioration being the strongest indicators.

questions.text: In managing intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) during surgery, what is the target systolic blood pressure (SBP)?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. < 120 mmHg: Is too low and may compromise cerebral perfusion.
  • • Option A. < 120 mmHg:
  • • Option C. < 160 mmHg: Was a previous recommendation but is now considered less optimal.
  • • Option C. < 160 mmHg:
  • • Option D. < 180 mmHg: Is too high and may not adequately control bleeding.
  • • Option D. < 180 mmHg:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the target SBP during ICH surgery, a crucial aspect of perioperative management.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with hypertension and smoking presents with sudden severe "thunderclap" headache, nausea, and photophobia. CT reveals subarachnoid hemorrhage, and angiography shows a 7 mm berry aneurysm in the anterior communicating artery. Which factor most significantly increases the risk of rupture?

options.label: A
options.text: Location in the anterior communicating artery

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Location in the anterior communicating artery: Location can influence risk, but size is more significant.
  • • Option A. Location in the anterior communicating artery:
  • • Option C. History of hypertension: Hypertension is a risk factor for aneurysm formation and growth, but not the strongest predictor of rupture.
  • • Option C. History of hypertension:
  • • Option D. History of smoking: Smoking is a risk factor, but again, not as directly predictive as size.
  • • Option D. History of smoking:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that aneurysm size is the most critical factor in determining rupture risk.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man experiences a sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache while playing basketball. He has a stiff neck, photophobia, and CT reveals subarachnoid hemorrhage. Angiography shows a 4 mm aneurysm in the middle cerebral artery. Which grading scale is most appropriate to assess his SAH?

options.label: D
options.text: World Federation of Neurological Surgeons (WFNS) grading system

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS): GCS assesses level of consciousness but not the specific severity of SAH.
  • • Option A.
  • • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):
  • • Option C. Modified Rankin Scale: Modified Rankin Scale measures disability after stroke, not acute SAH severity.
  • • Option C.
  • • Modified Rankin Scale:
  • • Option D. World Federation of Neurological Surgeons (WFNS) grading system: WFNS grading system is another SAH scale, but Hunt and Hess is more commonly used for initial assessment.
  • • Option D.
  • • World Federation of Neurological Surgeons (WFNS) grading system:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the role of the Hunt and Hess scale in assessing the severity and prognosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: On day 5 post-SAH, a patient becomes confused and lethargic with a serum sodium of 125 mEq/L (down from 138 mEq/L). Fluid intake has been restricted, and there are no signs of edema or dehydration. What is the most likely cause of hyponatremia?

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebral salt wasting (CSW) due to SAH

questions.correct_answer: C. Cerebral salt wasting (CSW) due to SAH
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Excessive hypotonic fluids: Excessive fluids would cause fluid overload, not seen here.
  • • Option A. Excessive hypotonic fluids:
  • • Option B. SIADH secondary to SAH: SIADH would present with euvolemia or fluid overload.
  • • Option B. SIADH secondary to SAH:
  • • Option D. Adrenal insufficiency: Adrenal insufficiency is less common and usually involves hypotension and hyperkalemia.
  • • Option D. Adrenal insufficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize CSW as a potential cause of hyponatremia in SAH, differentiated from SIADH by volume status.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with poorly controlled hypertension presents with a sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache, nausea, and vomiting. She is drowsy with a stiff neck and positive Kernig's sign. CT reveals SAH and angiography shows a 5 mm aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Options A & B. Clipping or coiling are definitive treatments but not the immediate priority.
  • • Options A & B.
  • • Option D. Corticosteroids are not indicated for SAH.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the importance of nimodipine for preventing vasospasm in the acute management of SAH.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with SAH becomes increasingly confused and lethargic on day 5 of hospitalization. Her serum sodium is 125 mEq/L (decreased from baseline). Her fluid intake has been restricted. What is the most likely cause of hyponatremia?

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebral salt wasting (CSW) due to SAH

questions.correct_answer: C. Cerebral salt wasting (CSW) due to SAH
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Excessive hypotonic fluids: Excessive fluid administration is unlikely given fluid restriction.
  • • Option A. Excessive hypotonic fluids:
  • • Option B. SIADH secondary to SAH: SIADH would present with euvolemia or hypervolemia, not hypovolemia.
  • • Option B. SIADH secondary to SAH:
  • • Option D. Adrenal insufficiency: Adrenal insufficiency is less common and presents with hypotension and hyperkalemia.
  • • Option D. Adrenal insufficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize CSW as a potential cause of hyponatremia in SAH, differentiating it from SIADH by the presence of hypovolemia.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with hypertension and smoking presents with sudden severe headache, confusion, and visual disturbances. He has bilateral papilledema and flame-shaped hemorrhages on fundoscopy. Brain MRI shows diffuse cerebral edema but no infarction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute ischemic stroke: Ischemic stroke would show focal deficits and infarction on MRI.
  • • Option A. Acute ischemic stroke:
  • • Option C. Meningitis: Meningitis would typically present with fever and neck stiffness.
  • • Option C. Meningitis:
  • • Option D. Intracerebral haemorrhage: Intracerebral hemorrhage would show a focal bleed on MRI.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with severe atherosclerosis has sudden paralysis and loss of pain and temperature sensation in both legs, along with urinary retention. Vibration and proprioception are intact. What is the LEAST likely cause?

Ans.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has progressive lower back pain radiating to both legs, difficulty initiating urination, fecal incontinence, decreased perineal sensation, and weakness in ankle muscles. MRI shows a mass lesion at L1. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans.

  • • Option C. Lumbar disc herniation: Typically affects one leg more than the other.
  • • Option C. Lumbar disc herniation:
  • • Option D. Spinal stenosis: Causes gradual pain and weakness.
  • • Option D. Spinal stenosis:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with severe lower back pain radiating to both legs, saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, fecal incontinence, decreased saddle sensation, and weakness in the lower extremities. Straight leg raise test is positive bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans.

  • • Option C. Disc herniation:
  • • Option D. Spinal stenosis : Causes gradual pain and weakness.
  • • Option D. Spinal stenosis

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with generalized muscle weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles, reduced muscle tone, absent reflexes, and a "frog-leg" posture. There is no family history of neuromuscular disorders. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • • Option A. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
  • • Option B. Myotonic dystrophy : Myotonic dystrophy is characterized by myotonia (delayed muscle relaxation) and typically has a later onset.
  • • Option B. Myotonic dystrophy
  • • Option D. Congenital myopathy : Congenital myopathies are a diverse group of muscle disorders present at birth with varying presentations.
  • • Option D. Congenital myopathy

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with progressive right-hand weakness, muscle cramps, twitching, difficulty swallowing, slurred speech, and emotional lability. Exam reveals intrinsic hand muscle atrophy, fasciculations, increased tone, hyperreflexia, and bulbar muscle weakness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Multiple sclerosis (MS): MS typically has a relapsing-remitting course with multifocal neurological deficits.
  • • Option B. Multiple sclerosis (MS):
  • • Option C. Myasthenia gravis (MG): MG causes fluctuating weakness that worsens with use and improves with rest.
  • • Option C. Myasthenia gravis (MG):
  • • Option D. Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS): GBS is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy with ascending weakness.
  • • Option D. Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the classic presentation of ALS, a neurodegenerative disease affecting both upper and lower motor neurons.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a 1-year history of progressive weakness in the left hand and arm, difficulty with speech and swallowing, muscle atrophy and fasciculations in the left arm, spasticity in the legs, hyperreflexia, slurred speech, and tongue weakness has a mild restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. Which medication can slow the progression of this disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Pyridostigmine : Pyridostigmine is used for myasthenia gravis.
  • • Option B. Pyridostigmine
  • • Option C. Prednisone : Prednisone is a corticosteroid used for inflammatory conditions.
  • • Option C. Prednisone
  • • Option D. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) : IVIG is used for immune-mediated conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome.
  • • Option D. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that riluzole is the only medication shown to have a modest effect on slowing the progression of ALS.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of intermittent numbness and tingling in her right arm and leg, blurred vision in her left eye that resolved spontaneously, fatigue, and difficulty with balance. Exam reveals decreased sensation in the right arm and leg, intention tremor, and a positive Romberg sign. MRI shows multiple demyelinating lesions in the brain and spinal cord, some enhancing with gadolinium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS): GBS typically presents with ascending weakness and areflexia.
  • • Option A. Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS):
  • • Option C. Stroke: Stroke typically causes sudden onset of focal deficits.
  • • Option C. Stroke:
  • • Option D. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms but not the typical MRI findings of MS.
  • • Option D. Vitamin B12 deficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the typical presentation and MRI findings of multiple sclerosis, a chronic inflammatory demyelinating disease of the CNS.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of two previous MS relapses presents with sudden severe left leg weakness and numbness. Exam reveals marked weakness and decreased sensation in the left leg. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Plasmapheresis: Plasmapheresis is considered for severe relapses not responding to corticosteroids.
  • • Option B. Plasmapheresis:
  • • Option C. Interferon beta-1a: Interferon beta-1a is a disease-modifying therapy for long-term management, not acute relapses.
  • • Option C. Interferon beta-1a:
  • • Option D. Oral corticosteroids: Oral corticosteroids may be used for less severe relapses or as a taper after IV steroids.
  • • Option D. Oral corticosteroids:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the use of high-dose intravenous corticosteroids as the initial treatment for acute relapses in multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is diagnosed with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) after an episode of optic neuritis and MRI findings of demyelinating lesions. He's had two relapses requiring corticosteroids. He now has mild left-sided weakness and decreased sensation in his right leg. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for his MS?

options.label: A
options.text: High-dose intravenous corticosteroids as maintenance therapy

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. High-dose intravenous corticosteroids as maintenance therapy: High-dose IV corticosteroids are for acute relapses, not maintenance.
  • • Option A. High-dose intravenous corticosteroids as maintenance therapy:
  • • Option C. Plasmapheresis : Plasmapheresis is for severe, refractory relapses.
  • • Option C. Plasmapheresis
  • • Option D. Natalizumab: Natalizumab is a second-line option due to the risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML).
  • • Option D. Natalizumab:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the role of interferon beta-1a as a first-line disease-modifying therapy for RRMS.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with sudden right-sided weakness and difficulty with coordination, as well as a prior episode of transient left-sided facial numbness. Which finding best supports a diagnosis of MS according to the McDonald criteria?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of both brain and spinal cord lesions on MRI

options.label: B
options.text: Demonstration of dissemination in space (DIS) and time (DIT) on MRI

options.label: C
options.text: Detection of oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid

questions.correct_answer: B. Demonstration of dissemination in space (DIS) and time (DIT) on MRI
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Presence of both brain and spinal cord lesions on MRI: While this shows DIS, it doesn't confirm DIT.
  • • Option A. Presence of both brain and spinal cord lesions on MRI:
  • • Option C. Detection of oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid: Oligoclonal bands are supportive, but not the primary criterion.
  • • Option C. Detection of oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid:
  • • Option D. History of multiple neurological symptoms: Multiple episodes are suggestive, but MRI findings are more definitive.
  • • Option D. History of multiple neurological symptoms:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the importance of demonstrating dissemination in space and time on MRI for diagnosing MS according to the McDonald criteria.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with RRMS on natalizumab for 2 years presents with progressive weakness, confusion, personality changes, and new non-enhancing white matter lesions on MRI. Which serious side effect of natalizumab is suggested?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM): ADEM is an acute inflammatory demyelinating disorder not specifically linked to natalizumab.
  • • Option B. Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM):
  • • Option C. Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM): CPM is associated with rapid correction of hyponatremia.
  • • Option C. Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM):
  • • Option D. MS rebound syndrome: MS rebound is a potential risk after stopping natalizumab, not while on it.
  • • Option D. MS rebound syndrome:

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with worsening vision in her right eye, eye pain with movement, recent severe back pain, and leg weakness/numbness. Exam reveals vision loss in the right eye with RAPD and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM) on spinal MRI. Serum AQP4 antibodies are positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • The combination of optic neuritis, LETM on MRI, and positive AQP4 antibodies is highly specific for NMOSD.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Multiple sclerosis (MS): MS can have similar symptoms, but the LETM and AQP4 antibodies are more characteristic of NMOSD.
  • • Option A. Multiple sclerosis (MS):
  • • Option C. Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM): ADEM is an acute demyelinating disorder, not usually associated with AQP4 antibodies.
  • • Option C. Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM):
  • • Option D. Optic neuritis of unknown etiology: Isolated optic neuritis is less likely given the spinal cord involvement and positive AQP4 antibodies.
  • • Option D. Optic neuritis of unknown etiology:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the distinct clinical and laboratory features of NMOSD, differentiating it from MS.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT part of the 2015 International Consensus Diagnostic Criteria for NMOSD?

options.label: B
options.text: An episode of optic neuritis, myelitis, or area postrema syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF

options.label: D
options.text: At least one core clinical characteristic in the absence of AQP4-IgG

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • :
  • • Option A. Positive aquaporin-4 antibody (AQP4-IgG) serostatus, Option B. An episode of optic neuritis, myelitis, or area postrema syndrome and Option D. At least one core clinical characteristic in the absence of AQP4-IgG are all part of the diagnostic criteria for NMOSD.
  • • Option A. Positive aquaporin-4 antibody (AQP4-IgG) serostatus, Option B. An episode of optic neuritis, myelitis, or area postrema syndrome
  • • Option D. At least one core clinical characteristic in the absence of AQP4-IgG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the specific diagnostic criteria for NMOSD, including the importance of AQP4 antibodies and core clinical characteristics.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with sudden-onset fever, headache, confusion, hyperreflexia, and bilateral Babinski signs following a recent upper respiratory tract infection. MRI shows multiple, bilateral, asymmetric lesions involving both white and gray matter with no enhancement after contrast administration. Lumbar puncture reveals mild lymphocytic pleocytosis with normal glucose and elevated protein levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Multiple sclerosis (MS): MS typically has a relapsing-remitting course and more discrete lesions on MRI.

  • • Option C. Bacterial meningitis: Bacterial meningitis usually presents with higher fever, nuchal rigidity, and CSF findings of elevated neutrophils and low glucose.
  • • Option C. Bacterial meningitis:
  • • Option D. Cerebral abscesses: Cerebral abscesses typically cause focal neurological deficits and appear as ring-enhancing lesions on MRI.
  • • Option D. Cerebral abscesses:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most common cause of mononeuropathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Autoimmune diseases: Autoimmune diseases more commonly cause multiple nerve involvement (polyneuropathy).

  • • Option D. Infectious diseases: Infectious diseases can cause neuropathy, but it's less common than compression/trauma as a cause of mononeuropathy.
  • • Option D. Infectious diseases:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with chronic lower back pain and burning/electric shock-like pain radiating down her left leg has sensory loss in the L5 dermatome. She is cautious about using NSAIDs due to peptic ulcer disease. Which is NOT a first-line treatment for her pain?

questions.text: A 23-year-old man has progressive ascending weakness in both legs and arms over 2 days, preceded by a diarrheal illness 10 days prior. Exam reveals symmetrical weakness, areflexia, and mild sensory loss. CSF shows elevated protein with normal white cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Option D. Myasthenia gravis (MG): MG causes fluctuating weakness that worsens with use.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man has progressive difficulty walking, double vision, and incomplete eyelid closure over the past week, preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks prior. He has bilateral limb weakness, areflexia, and normal sensation. Lumbar puncture shows elevated protein with normal white cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans.

  • • :

questions.text: A patient with GBS is admitted to the ICU due to rapidly progressive weakness and respiratory distress. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and Option C. Plasmapheresis: While IVIG and plasmapheresis are effective treatments for GBS, they are immunomodulatory therapies that take time to work. They are not the immediate priority in a patient with respiratory distress.
  • • Option A. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)
  • • Option C. Plasmapheresis:
  • • Option B. Oral corticosteroids: Corticosteroids are not beneficial in GBS and may even worsen the outcome.
  • • Option B. Oral corticosteroids:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that the immediate priority in managing a patient with GBS and respiratory distress is to secure the airway and initiate mechanical ventilation before considering immunomodulatory therapies.

questions.text: A patient with rapidly ascending muscle weakness, areflexia, and mild sensory loss following gastroenteritis has a lumbar puncture. What CSF finding is most indicative of their condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Significantly elevated WBCs with lymphocytic predominance

Ans.

Explanation:

  • • :

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with rapidly progressing ascending weakness and tingling is diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. High-dose oral corticosteroids : Corticosteroids are not beneficial in GBS.

  • • Option C. Plasmapheresis : Plasmapheresis is an alternative to IVIG.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness worsening in the evening, difficulty keeping her eyelids open, double vision, and difficulty chewing. Symptoms improve with rest. Exam shows bilateral ptosis and diplopia on sustained upward gaze. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a smoking history has progressive proximal muscle weakness, dry mouth, erectile dysfunction, and a cough. The weakness improves with continued use. Exam shows proximal muscle weakness, diminished reflexes at rest with incremental response upon repetitive stimulation. A chest CT reveals a lung mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with complaints of double vision and drooping eyelids, especially at the end of the day or after prolonged reading. She also reports difficulty swallowing and arm weakness after repetitive tasks. Her symptoms improve after resting. On examination, she has bilateral ptosis and diplopia with sustained upward gaze. Acetylcholine receptor antibodies are positive. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • • Option D. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) therapy : IVIG is reserved for acute exacerbations or refractory MG.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents with muscle weakness in her neck and bulbar muscles, difficulty holding her head upright, and problems with speech and swallowing. She also reports double vision. Symptoms have worsened over 6 months. Acetylcholine receptor antibodies are negative, but muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies are positive. Pyridostigmine provides minimal improvement. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.text: Initiate corticosteroids and consider adding rituximab.

Ans.

  • • Option C. Schedule immediate thymectomy : Thymectomy is less beneficial in MuSK MG.

  • • Option D. Prescribe cholinesterase inhibitors as the sole treatment : Cholinesterase inhibitors alone are insufficient for MuSK MG.

questions.text: In patients with myasthenia gravis, thymectomy is most commonly indicated in which scenario?

options.label: C
options.text: Patients with thymoma, regardless of symptom severity

Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :

  • • Option B. Patients with purely ocular symptoms : Thymectomy is considered less often in ocular MG.

  • • Option D. Patients in medication-induced remission : Medication-induced remission does not negate the need for thymectomy if a thymoma is present.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with difficulty running, frequent falls, Gowers' sign, and calf pseudohypertrophy. He was late to start walking and has always been clumsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Ans.

  • • Option D. Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease (CMT) : CMT primarily affects the peripheral nerves, leading to distal weakness and sensory loss.

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) findings is most commonly associated with myasthenia gravis?

  • • Option D. Prolonged direct muscle stimulation response : Prolonged direct muscle stimulation response is not characteristic of MG.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with difficulty running, frequent falls, and using Gowers' sign to stand up. He has calf muscle hypertrophy and elevated serum creatine kinase (CK) levels. What is the diagnosis?

  • • :
  • • Option A. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) : DMD presents earlier in childhood (3-5 years) with more rapid progression.
  • • Option A. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)
  • • Option C. Myotonic Dystrophy : Myotonic dystrophy is associated with myotonia, facial weakness, and multisystem involvement.
  • • Option C. Myotonic Dystrophy
  • • Option D. Limb-Girdle Muscular Dystrophy : Limb-Girdle MD affects shoulders and hips, not calves.
  • • Option D. Limb-Girdle Muscular Dystrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Differentiate Becker MD from Duchenne MD based on age of onset and clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with difficulty releasing his grip (myotonia), muscle stiffness, facial weakness, temporalis and masseter muscle atrophy, cataracts, daytime sleepiness, and constipation. EMG shows myotonic discharges. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Polymyositis : Polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy with proximal muscle weakness and elevated muscle enzymes.
  • • Option A. Polymyositis
  • • Option B. Myasthenia gravis : Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating weakness, often with ocular involvement.
  • • Option B. Myasthenia gravis
  • • Option D. Multiple sclerosis : Multiple sclerosis is a demyelinating disease with a wide range of symptoms.
  • • Option D. Multiple sclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the multisystemic manifestations of myotonic dystrophy.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with muscle weakness, elbow contractures, weak upper arm and calf muscles, mild scoliosis, and ECG conduction abnormalities:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Facioscapulohumeral Muscular Dystrophy (FSHD) : FSHD typically affects facial, shoulder, and upper arm muscles without early contractures or significant cardiac involvement.
  • • Option A. Facioscapulohumeral Muscular Dystrophy (FSHD)
  • • Option C. Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) : BMD presents with later onset and predominantly affects proximal muscles.
  • • Option C. Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD)
  • • Option D. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) : DMD has an earlier onset and more severe progression.
  • • Option D. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the early contractures and cardiac involvement as key features of Emery-Dreifuss Muscular Dystrophy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman has progressive numbness, tingling, and burning pain in her hands and feet, worse at night. Examination shows loss of pinprick and temperature sensation in a stocking-glove distribution. Nerve conduction studies are normal, but a skin biopsy shows reduced intraepidermal nerve fiber density. What is least likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Diabetes mellitus : Diabetes is a common cause of small fiber neuropathy.
  • • Option A. Diabetes mellitus
  • • Option B. Alcohol : Alcohol is a common cause of small fiber neuropathy.
  • • Option B. Alcohol
  • • Option C. Chemotherapy : Chemotherapy can cause small fiber neuropathy.
  • • Option C. Chemotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize small fiber neuropathy as a distinct entity and be aware of its common causes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female complains of numbness and tingling in her thumb, index finger, and middle finger. Symptoms are worse at night and improve with shaking her hand. Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Ulnar nerve : The ulnar nerve supplies the little finger and the ulnar half of the ring finger. Compression of this nerve would result in symptoms in these fingers.
  • • Option A. Ulnar nerve
  • • Option B. Radial nerve : The radial nerve supplies the back of the hand and the thumb side of the forearm. Compression of this nerve would cause weakness and sensory loss in these areas.
  • • Option B. Radial nerve
  • • Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve : The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the muscles of the front of the upper arm and the skin on the radial side of the forearm. Compression of this nerve would cause weakness in elbow flexion and sensory loss in the forearm.
  • • Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the classic presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome, including the distribution of symptoms and the characteristic features of worsening at night and improvement with shaking the hand. This knowledge is essential for early diagnosis and appropriate management.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is known to cause peripheral neuropathy as a side effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Metformin : Metformin is an oral antidiabetic medication. It is not typically associated with peripheral neuropathy.
  • • Option A. Metformin
  • • Option B. Atorvastatin : Atorvastatin is a statin medication used to lower cholesterol levels. While rare cases of muscle pain (myopathy) have been reported, peripheral neuropathy is not a common side effect.
  • • Option B. Atorvastatin
  • • Option C. Lisinopril : Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. It is not known to cause peripheral neuropathy.
  • • Option C. Lisinopril

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Be aware that amiodarone can cause peripheral neuropathy as a side effect and monitor patients on this medication for neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of monoclonal gammopathy presents with progressive weakness and sensory loss in his legs. Nerve conduction studies reveal demyelinating neuropathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) : While CIDP is a demyelinating neuropathy, it is not typically associated with monoclonal gammopathies.
  • • Option A. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP)
  • • Option B. Diabetic peripheral neuropathy : Diabetic neuropathy is usually axonal, not demyelinating, and it presents with a more symmetrical, length-dependent pattern.
  • • Option B. Diabetic peripheral neuropathy
  • • Option D. Paraneoplastic neuropathy : Paraneoplastic neuropathies are associated with underlying cancers and can present with various patterns, but the presence of monoclonal gammopathy points more towards amyloid neuropathy.
  • • Option D. Paraneoplastic neuropathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that monoclonal gammopathy in a patient with progressive demyelinating neuropathy should raise a strong suspicion for amyloid neuropathy. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential for managing this condition.
